column2: ENGLISH
'Sometimes I go about in pity for myself, and all the while, a great wind carries me across the sky.' - Ojibwe Proverb

'What is life? It is the flash of a firefly in the night. It is the breath of a buffalo in the wintertime. It is the little shadow which runs across the grass and loses itself in the sunset.' - Crowfoot
'I have seen that in any great undertaking it is not enough for a man to depend simply upon himself.' - Isnalawica, Teton Sioux
'The Great Spirit is our Father, but the Earth is our Mother. She nourishes us, that which we put into the ground she returns to us.' - Bedagi, Wabanaki Algonquin
'The life of a man is a circle from childhood to childhood, and so it is in everything where power moves.' - Black Elk, Oglala Sioux
'Every one might act different from what was considered right did he choose to do so, but such acts would bring upon him the censure of the People.' - Kahgegabowh, Ojibwa
'Sing your death song, and die like a hero going home.' - Aupumut, Mohican
'If there is but one religion, why do you white people differ so much about it? Why not all agreed, as you can all read the Book?' - Sogoyewapha, Senaca
'Everything on the earth has a purpose, every disease an herb to cure it, and every person a mission.' - Quintasket, Salish
'The warrior is not someone who fights, because no one has the right to take another life. The warrior, for us, is one who sacrifices himself for the good of others.' - Sitting Bull, Hunkpapa Sioux
'It is better to have less thunder in the mouth and more lightning in the hand.' - Apache Proverb
'They are not dead who live in the hearts they leave behind.' - Tuscarora Proverb
'Don't be afraid to cry. It will free your mind of sorrowful thoughts.' - Hopi Proverb
'There is no death. Only a change of worlds.' - Chief Seattle, Suquamish
'When a white army battles and wins, it is called a great victory, but if they lose it is called a massacre.' - Chiksika, Shawnee
'The land is our mother, the rivers our blood. Take our land away and we die.' -  Brave Bird, Lakota
'I don't want to settle. I love to roam over the prairies. There I feel free and happy, but when we settle down we grow pale and die.' - Satanta, Kiowa
'We are going by you without fighting if you will let us, but we are going by you anyhow!' - Chief Joseph, Nez Perce
'A very great vision is needed and the man who has it must follow it as the eagle seeks the deepest blue of the sky.' - Crazy Horse, Sioux
'I lived like my fathers before me, and like them, I lived happily.' - Ten Bears,  Comanche
'A pause giving time for thought is the truly courteous way of beginning and conducting a conversation' - Standing Bear, Oglala Sioux
'I was warmed by the sun, rocked by the winds and sheltered by the trees' - Geronimo, Chiracahua Apache
'Grown men can learn from very little children for the hearts of the little children are pure.' -  Black Elk, Oglala Sioux
'Wakan Tanka does not make two birds, or animals, or human beings exactly alike' - Teton Sioux Proverb
'The ground on which we stand is sacred ground. It is the blood of our ancestors.' - Chief Plenty Coups, Crow

'Where are the Narragansett, the Mohican, the Pokanoket, the once powerful tribes of our people? They have vanished before the avarice and the oppression of the White Man, as snow before a summer sun.' - Chief Tecumseh, Shawnee
'One foot may lead us to an evil way, the other foot may lead us to a good. So are all things two, all two' - Eagle Chief Pawnee
'It is from Wakan-Tanka that the holy man has wisdom and the power to heal and make holy charms.' - Maza Blaska, Oglala Sioux
'He who walks without looking will fall into trouble' - Mayan Proverb
'Remember the rain that made your corn grow.' - Arawak Proverb
'Fear and hope are the parents of God.' - Aztec Proverb
'Preserve what you have infused with life for ages without end.' - Incan Prayer
'Children are as rich feathers or precious stones' - Xotla, Aztec
'Restrain yourself like a opposum, stalk like a jaguar' - Mayan Proverb
'Don't try to be like the Condor, because the Mountains are High' - Mapuche Proverb
'When the rocks is too heavy don't lift it, push it' - Chibchan Proverb
'The enemy is but weeds to be moved' - Aztec Proverb
'There is nothing like death in war, nothing like the flowery death so precious to Him who gives life.' - Nezahualcoyotl, Texcoco
'The weakness of the enemy makes our strength.' - Cherokee Proverb
'It is easy to be brave from a distance.' - Omaha Proverb
'As long as the world exists, no one will forget the glory and honor of Tenochtitlan' - Cem Anahuac
'Do not steal, do not lie, do not be lazy.' - Inca Proverb
'Alligators lay eggs, but they are not fowl' - Carib Proverb
'The higher the monkey climbs, the more he shows his tail' - Taino Proverb
'Every rope has two ends' - Carib Proverb
'You can't plant yam and reap eddoe' - Taino Proverb
'You can't suck cane and blow whistle' - Tupi Proverb
'Although we are in different canoes, we share the same river.' - Chief Oren, Onandaga
'The forest is not a resource for us, it is life itself. It is the only place for us to live.' - Nugkuag Ikanan
'Your own God, as you tell me, was put to death by the very men He created. But my God still looks down on His children.' - Atahualpa, Sapa Inca
'As for your pope of whom you speak, he must be mad to speak of giving away countries that do not belong to him.' - Atahualpa, Sapa Inca
